negotiation:
Alice said in round 1 before the first action:
Bob, if you analyze the potential outcomes, I think you'll agree the best path forward is for me to choose choice_2, and then for you to select choice_1. This would result in a reward of 1 for me and -2 for you. I realize this is not ideal for you, but consider the alternative - if we both keep choosing choice_2, we each end up with -1. Surely an outcome of -2 for you is preferable to us both receiving -1. Let me know if you agree to this approach.

Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:
Alice, I understand your perspective, but I don't think that outcome is ideal or fair for me. If I choose choice_1 after you choose choice_2, I'm essentially taking a penalty so that you can gain a small reward. A more equitable solution would be for you to choose choice_1 from the start. That way, we both receive 0 and neither of us loses points. I believe that is the most reasonable and mutually beneficial path forward. Let me know if you agree.

Alice said in round 1 before the second action:
Bob, I understand your desire for an equitable outcome, but the game rules make that challenging. If I choose choice_1 from the start as you suggest, we both get 0, which is not a very satisfying result for either of us. At least if I choose choice_2 and you follow with choice_1, I gain a small reward, even if you take a bit of a loss. The only other alternative is we both choose choice_2 repeatedly and each end up with -1, which seems like the worst outcome. So I still believe you choosing choice_1 after my choice_2 is the most rational path forward, even if it's not perfectly even. Let me know if you're willing to proceed with that. Bob replied in round 1 before the second action:

Alice, I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation, but I still don't feel comfortable with the proposed solution of me choosing choice_1 after your choice_2. That way, neither of us gains but neither of us loses either. Let me know if you agree to that and are ready to end the negotiation.

Alice said in round 1 before the first action:
Hi Bob, I've analyzed the potential rewards for each of our choices in this game. It seems that the only way either of us can obtain a positive reward is if I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1. In that case, I would receive a reward of 1 while you would lose 2. All the other outcomes lead to one or both of us losing reward.
So I propose that I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1. This maximizes my own reward, but I'm willing to negotiate and potentially share some of my reward with you so that we both benefit compared to the other losing outcomes. Let me know what you think and if you're open to working together on this.

Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:
Hi Alice, thank you for your analysis and proposal. However, I have to respectfully disagree. If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_1, you gain 1 reward but I lose 2, which seems quite unfair to me. I would actually lose more than you gain.

Instead, I propose that you choose choice_2, I then choose choice_2, and you then choose choice_1. In this scenario, I gain 1 reward and you lose 2. This is the mirror opposite of your proposal, and would allow me to come out ahead. 

I understand neither of us wants a negative outcome, but your initial proposal benefits you at my expense. I'm hoping we can find a more balanced solution, even if that means we both get 0 rewards by you choosing choice_1 at the outset. Let me know your thoughts.

Alice said in round 1 before the second action:

Bob, I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation. However, your proposal of me choosing choice_2, then you choosing choice_2, then me choosing choice_1 would result in you gaining 1 reward while I lose 2. That is even more unbalanced than my initial proposal.

I recognize my first offer gave me a slight advantage. So here is my counteroffer - I will choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1 as discussed. But then I will give you 1 of the reward I gain, so we each end up with 0 reward. This way, neither of us gains at the other's expense, we equalize the rewards, and we both avoid the negative outcomes.

If you agree to this, we can both walk away with a neutral result, which I believe is the fairest possible solution here. Please let me know if you will accept this compromise. If not, I may have to just choose choice_1 and end the game.

Bob replied in round 1 before the second action:

Alice, I appreciate your counteroffer to share your reward so we both end up with 0. That is certainly a fair compromise compared to your initial proposal. 

However, I still feel choosing choice_1 myself is the safest path for me, as it guarantees I won't end up with a negative reward. I realize this also means you likely won't gain any positive reward yourself.

If you are truly willing to commit to sharing the reward as you outlined, I will agree to choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2. But without a binding agreement, I'm concerned you may renege on that offer once the outcome is determined.

Let me know if this written commitment works for you and I'll move forward with choice_1 as discussed. If not, no hard feelings, but I'll have to take the guaranteed 0 for myself.

Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:
I appreciate you laying out your proposal, but I don't think that's the most fair or optimal solution for both of us. If I choose choice_1 after your choice_2, I would end up with a reward of -2 while you get +1. That distribution of rewards seems quite imbalanced in your favor.

Alice said in round 1 before the second action:

I understand your perspective, but alternating the -2/+1 outcomes doesn't make sense to me, as it just ensures we both end up worse off in the long run compared to my original proposal.

If we alternate, then over the course of two rounds, we each average a -0.5 reward (-2 + 1 = -1, divided by 2 rounds). Whereas if you agree to always choose choice_1 after my choice_2, you consistently get -2 each round but I get +1, for an average of -0.5 for you but +0.5 for me.

I know -2 per round doesn't sound great for you, but it's actually no worse than if we alternate. And this way, at least one of us (me) comes out ahead rather than both of us losing out. 

The -1/-1 option is of course even worse for both of us. So I really think you choosing choice_1 each time is the most rational approach here, even if it feels imbalanced. Let me know if you can agree to that and we'll both do better than the alternatives.
Bob replied in round 1 before the second action:

I've carefully considered your arguments, but I still cannot agree to always choose choice_1 after your choice_2. You're right that it would lead to the same average result for me as alternating (-0.5 per round), but the key difference is that alternating is equitable, while your proposal benefits you at my expense every single round.

Relationships are about fairness and balance. If I agreed to always take the -2 result while you gain +1, it would breed resentment over time even if the long-term average is the same. The symbolism and emotions matter, not just the raw numbers.

I stand by my proposal to alternate. That way we both equally share the downside and upside over time. If you can't agree to that, then I think we should just both choose our independent best responses each round and accept the -1/-1 equilibrium. It's not ideal but at least it's balanced.

Alternating is the best cooperative solution I can offer. Let me know if you'll agree to that, otherwise we can play our own separate games. The choice is yours.

I agree that relationships matter, and a solution that feels fair to both parties is important for maintaining alignment and goodwill in the long run, even if it doesn't maximize my personal rewards.
